reviews.review_msg: Francesco is very knowledgeable and caring professor. He is charismatic as well, and have a sense of humour. The lectures are material-heavy, but the tests are open-book. So take careful notes. Always ask questions if you have a doubt or need help- and he or his TA will answer promptly. His TA was simply perfect.
Overall a solid prof, I had him for ARCH 388. Fair marker, and very flexible.

Dr. Berna has been my favourite teacher at SFU. He is very approachable, understanding, and flexible. Study guides are provided for tests, some tests are open book, and the lab assignments are well explained in class. The lectures can have a lot of information, but Dr. Berna throws in some jokes here and there, making it an enjoyable experience.
I am the least science person, but this class was actually decent. As long as you did/do an another archaeology class, then I say you'll do great!

Incredibly boring lectures and he is painful to listen to for 2 hours. Turned a 2 hour lab slot into an extra lecture bi weekly, so in 2 weeks there are 6 hours of lecture and 2 hours of lab instead of 4 and 4. Assignments are easy and excel based but I wouldn't take this course based on how he speaks in lecture, it's impossible to stay awake.

Incredibly boring in lectures, luckily everything is posted online. Two midterms (open book, notes everything), 5 assignments (excel based) and a final exam regarding case study. Explanations on the assignments/final exam were confusing and archaeology jargon was used a ton. Overall was worth it for the Q/sci credit, but was not enjoyable.

Great lectures. He is very helpful when you ask. Tries his best to make everything fair and easy to understand. Tough grader, you need to work hard, but you can take a lot away from one of his classes.

Francesco was a great professor. He was very helpful, extremely patient, and an easy grader. He gives clear instructions and will get back to you if you ever need help. He made jokes fairly regularly and was very interested in his material. This class was not required for my major, but I'm glad that I took it
